description:
go.net/ipv4: Disable an example.

This is an example that isn't executed normally anyway
because the function has arguments. Adding an underscore prefix
makes it easier to exclude it from automated tools.

messages.text: This is weird. Why does the example have arguments, anyway?

Hello adg (cc: golang-dev@googlegroups.com),

I'd like you to review this change to
https://code.google.com/p/go.net

LGTM

probably worth discussing how to do this, but LGTM for now

On Sat, Sep 29, 2012 at 2:43 AM, Andrew Gerrand <adg@golang.org> wrote:

> Why does the example have arguments, anyway?

well, testing doc doesn't say don't do that, or I missed
such limitation.

LGTM I guess.

On Fri, Sep 28, 2012 at 4:58 PM,  <r@golang.org> wrote:
> LGTM
>
> probably worth discussing how to do this, but LGTM for now
>
> http://codereview.appspot.com/6570062/

*** Submitted as http://code.google.com/p/go/source/detail?r=e0dab2e41c13&repo=net ***

go.net/ipv4: Disable an example.

This is an example that isn't executed normally anyway
because the function has arguments. Adding an underscore prefix
makes it easier to exclude it from automated tools.

R=adg, r, dave
CC=golang-dev
http://codereview.appspot.com/6570062

On 29 September 2012 09:00, Mikio Hara <mikioh.mikioh@gmail.com> wrote:
> On Sat, Sep 29, 2012 at 2:43 AM, Andrew Gerrand <adg@golang.org> wrote:
>
>> Why does the example have arguments, anyway?
>
> well, testing doc doesn't say don't do that, or I missed
> such limitation.

I guess I never thought anyone would do that. I'm surprised the tests
still pass generally. I think that 'go test' just ignores such
examples

On Tue, Oct 2, 2012 at 7:55 AM, Andrew Gerrand <adg@golang.org> wrote:

> I guess I never thought anyone would do that.

hooray!

> I'm surprised the tests still pass generally.
> I think that 'go test' just ignores such examples

I will rewrite that example for safety, thanks.

subject: code review 6570062: go.net/ipv4: Disable an example.
